title: Building Micro-Frontends with Angular | Live Webinar | Coditas
desc: Micro-frontends are all the rage in the development industry right now! To understand the what, why, and how of Microfrontends with Angular, join our Director of Technology, Varun Srinivas for a knowledge-packed webinar.

title: Angular, Styling & View Encapsulation
desc: Angular has a fantastic approach to Component specific styling, which allows developers to confidently write styles without the fear of having those styles bleed over into other components or parts of the application, even if the class names that are defined are identical to those in other components. It does this via the default Emulated View Encapsulation Strategy.

title: Managing collections in Angular with NgRx ComponentStore and Entity
desc: NgRx Entity is a package for managing CRUD operations on collections of records. It works with NgRx Component Store similar to NgRx Store.

desc: In this article I show the simplest way to change theme in Angular application.

desc: In this lecture we will learn how to fetch data from the server and display that data in the web application. To fetch data from the server we use GET request and to send a GET request to the server, we can make use of get() method of HttpClient.

title: How to add push notifications in Angular
desc: It's no secret that push notifications can help you engage and retain app users. In this tutorial, we'll show you how to integrate with OneSignal in order to leverage push notifications in your Angular app.

title: Conditionally lazy load modules in Angular
desc: Recently, I faced a user scenario where I need to load a module for a route path conditionally. The scenario is that if a user is assigned with some permission, then load a module or load another module. The use case seems legit, but I was unable to achieve this using the current lazy loading module feature.

title: E077 - MFE Episode 2: Single SPA

We also learn from Joel a few strategies for sharing dependencies, such as module federation or SystemJS.

title: Domain Driven Design with NgRx
desc: In this article we showed how we can think about how the implementation to NgRx can be similar to the implementation of domain driven design. Both NgRx and Domain Driven Design rely heavily on events occurring in the system to derive the state of the system / application. We can also see how NgRx is similar to the CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Separation) that is a tenant of Domain Driven Design.

title: How to fix 'ng: command not found' in Angular

title: Native Shadow DOM vs Emulated Shadow DOM
desc:
In Angular, components styles can be encapsulated. There are three different encapsulation strategies available. None, Emulated and ShadowDom.

None is probably the least interesting. It just disables encapsulation completely. But what is the difference between Emulated and ShadowDom? Let's find out!

title: Directives in Angular
desc: Directives are one of the most important concepts in Angular, In this section, we will see what is a directive and its types and how to create our own directives

title: Angular: How to use @HostListener
desc: In this article, I'll show you some simple examples of how to use this decorator. All the examples assume the following method names: 'on' + event name, for example, 'onScroll()'.

title: NgRx — How to deal with large stores in Angular
desc: NgRx is the state of the art implementation in Angular2+ projects to handle http requests and store data in a local store. NgRx provides many benefits, especially in large projects. Unfortunately large projects use an increasing number of http requests and data objects, so that the NgRx store is increasing as well. Both the number of state objects and actions and the complexity of the store become difficult to deal with. This article introduces solutions to make store contents more clear.

title: Observable vs Subject in Angular with example
desc: An RxJS Observable stream of events to which observers can subscribe. Observable is unicast.

title: Angular ngModules and lazy loading: split applications into features, shared and core modules

title: Angular Utilities Init Directive
desc:
I bet if you are an Angular developer you're dealing with streams on a daily basis. Since RxJS is an essential part of the framework.

There are two ways of getting data from the stream. You either subscribe on the Observable explicitly by calling a subscribe() method, or use a built-in async pipe which is preferable cause it's handling unsubscribing for you.

Creating a CI pipeline for Angular
desc: An advantage of having our repository on Azure Devops is that it allows us to run automatic tests on new codes that are pushed. To achieve this, a build (a compiled version of the code) is created and tests are run against it so as to evaluate code coverage or linting. Running various tests ensure that the code quality is acceptable and, if so, the new code can be merged.

title: How to switch between Angular SSR and CSR based on detecting user-agent

For example, the transitions between pages could be slowed down if your site traffics get high. there are a lot of pros and cons for SSR and CSR I'm not digging into them. What we want here is to have both of them at the same time. We want SSR for SEO and CSR for users.
